sources.snippet: एक छोटे से द्वीप पर स्थित विवेकानंद रॉक मेमोरियल कन्याकुमारी में एक शीर्ष पर्यटन स्थल है। स्वामी विवेकानंद ने 1892 में तीन दिनों के ध्यान के बाद यहां ज्ञान प्राप्त किया था। यह भी माना जाता है कि देवी कन्याकुमारी ने इस चट्टान पर घोर तपस्या की थी। रॉक मेमोरियल के प्रमुख आकर्षण विवेकानंद मंडपम और श्रीपाद मंडपम हैं। बैकग्राउंड में हिंद महासागर के साथ एक विशाल स्वामीजी की मूर्ति देखने लायक है। इस जगह पर जाना का सबसे अच्छा समय अक्टूबर से मार्च का महीना है।. ये हैं चेन्नई के बेस्ट रोड ट्रिप्स जो ले जाएंगे आपको इन ऑफ बीट डेस्टिनेशन तक

sources.snippet: Vivekananda Rock Memorial built in memory of Swami Vivekananda, is set in such a picturesque setting that you’d want to linger on in the place for a longer time. The Memorial consists of a Mandapam which has a life sized idol of Swami Vivekananda and a meditation hall where one can sit in quiet contemplation. Facing the Mandapam is another mandapam called Sri Padaparai with a rock in the sanctum, which has the raised impression of a footprint, which according to legends was made by Goddess Kanyakumari.
sources.shortName: Tourist Places To Visit In Kanyakumari (2025)

sources.snippet: Built-in the memory of the great religious reformer, Swami Vivekananda, Vivekananda Rock Memorial is one of the top attractions of Kanyakumari that must be on your bucket list. Comprising two main structures -the Vivekananda Mandapam and the Shripada Mandapam, this historical monument in Kanyakumari is an architectural wonder which is approximately 500 meters away from the mainland. The life-size statue of Swami Vivekananda is the most attractive feature of the memorial which was inaugurated in 1970.
sources.shortName: Top 7 Attractions of Kanyakumari | Azure Waters & Picture Perfect Sunsets

sources.snippet: Revered Indian poet and Hindu philosopher Swami Vivekananda visited Kanyakumari in 1892, towards the end of an extensive trip across India as a wandering monk. His transformation into an influential leader and reformer is attributed to the three days he spent meditating on a large offshore rock, where Goddess Kanya Kumari is said to have carried out part of her penance by standing on one foot. According to ancient Hindu texts, the Puranas, the rock was blessed by the touch of her foot.
sources.shortName: Top Things to Do in Kanyakumari, Tamil Nadu

sources.snippet: Dedicated to Swami Vivekananda, a religious reformer, the Vivekananda Rock Memorial is one of the most popular tourist attraction in Kanyakumari. Covering an area of six acres, the rock memorial is situated at an island a few metres into the sea and positioned at a level of 17 metres above the sea level. Apart from that, a statue of celebrated Tamil poet, Thiruvalluvar, standing tall, almost at the confluence of the three seas, is a major tourist place.
sources.shortName: Kanyakumari Tourism- Best Places to Visit in Kanyakumari

sources.snippet: The magnificent Vivekananda Rock Memorial, situated just at the merger of the beautiful Arabian Sea, Bay of Bengal and Indian ocean is one of the major locations of Kanyakumari and Tamil Nadu. It is dedicated to the greatest philosopher of the century Swami Vivekananda, as it is said that Vivekananda got enlightenment while he was meditating on this rock in his early monk days. It is located exactly on a rock amidst the sea, where you can reach by boat.

reviews.reviewText: Good tourist spot. Price was reasonable. Week days were not crowded. Boat service was good but the life jacket could have maintained properly. The glass bridge was mesmerizing.

Vivekananda Rock Memorial – Beautiful, But Be Prepared

The Vivekananda Rock Memorial is undoubtedly a serene and inspiring place, rich in history and spiritual significance. The view from the rock, surrounded by the endless sea and with the mainland in the distance, is truly breathtaking. It’s a powerful spot where you can reflect and feel deeply connected to nature and Swami Vivekananda’s legacy.

However, the experience getting there was less than ideal. Despite purchasing the ₹300 ferry ticket, we still had to stand in a long, exhausting queue under the scorching sun, with minimal shade or crowd management. It was quite frustrating, especially considering the premium ticket.

Additionally, there’s a separate entrance fee for the temple once you reach the rock, which felt a bit excessive after already paying for the ferry ride. The heat and waiting time took away from the peacefulness we were hoping for.

Tips:

Carry a hat, sunglasses, and water — the sun can be relentless.
Try to visit early in the morning to avoid both the heat and long queues.
Be mentally prepared for the wait, even with a higher-priced ticket.
It’s a must-see spot for its spiritual and scenic value, but a bit of planning (and patience) is necessary to truly enjoy it.

The very sight of Vivekananda Rock from a distance fills you with a deep sense of peace and awe. Once you arrive, be prepared for a wait — even on weekdays, the queue can take around 45 minutes. You can choose between ₹100 or ₹300 tickets depending on your preference, but whichever you choose, the journey is well worth it.

Once you’re there, the calm of the rock, the spiritual energy of the place, the stunning architecture of the memorial, and the majestic Tiruvalluvar statue leave a lasting impression. The glass bridge adds a unique touch to the experience.

Note: There are no food stalls on the premises, so plan your visit after a hearty breakfast or lunch. Free drinking water is available, and there’s a small shop where you can buy books and souvenirs to take a part of the experience home.

A must-visit for those seeking serenity, inspiration, and a connection with India’s spiritual legacy.

Vivekananda Rock memorial is a neatly maintained spot to visit. We need to take the ferry to visit. The ferry service will start around 8 AM in the morning and there will be a long fast moving queue for a 100 rs ticket and for a 300 rs ticket the queue will be very less. But the long queue itself will move faster. In a single trip they'll take around 80+ people i guess. So the queue will move fast. 300 rs ticket ppl will have the first priority to board on the ferry but while returning the 300 rs ticket won't work. All 100 and 300 will have to wait in the same queue to board the ferry to return to the mainland.

Vivekananda Rock Memorial, located off the coast of Kanyakumari, is a truly serene and awe-inspiring destination. Perched on a rocky island where the Arabian Sea, Bay of Bengal, and Indian Ocean converge, the memorial offers a breathtaking panoramic view of the endless blue waters. The structure itself, dedicated to Swami Vivekananda, is a blend of spiritual energy and architectural beauty.

A must-visit spiritual and scenic marvel!
Vivekananda Rock Memorial is truly awe-inspiring—located right at the confluence of three seas, the view is absolutely breathtaking. The ferry ride adds to the charm, and the peaceful meditation hall (Dhyana Mandapam) offers a serene escape from the noise of daily life. The architecture is elegant, and the energy here is powerful. Best visited during sunrise or sunset for an unforgettable experience

A must-visit iconic place in Kanyakumari! Located on a small rocky island surrounded by the sea, this memorial is dedicated to Swami Vivekananda, who meditated here before beginning his spiritual journey. The boat ride to the rock is a unique experience, offering stunning views of the ocean on all sides.

A lovely quick boat ride to get there. We arrived on a marvellous sunny day. Although breezy was welcome. You do need to be aware you need to remove your shoes. Stay on light colours when walking.
Well worth the visit.

placeMetadata.name: Thiruvalluvar Statue

sources.snippet: A 133 ft tall stone sculpture of the greatest Tamil poet and philosopher, Valluvar is one of the must-visit tourist attractions of Kanyakumari. Opened to the public in 2000, the Thiruvalluvar Statue stands on a three-tier pedestal that is etched with 38 chapters of Thirukkural which was the first book written by the poet, Thiruvalluvar. Despite its massive dimensions and weight of 7000 tons, the statue was swallowed by the tidal turbulence during the Tsunami in 2004 but the statue was restored to its original glory as it is considered to be the landmark of Kanyakumari.

reviews.reviewText:
I recently visited the Thiruvalluvar Statue in Kanyakumari, and it was an unforgettable experience. The statue is located on a small island surrounded by the sea, and now there’s a newly built glass sea bridge that connects the Vivekananda Rock Memorial and the Thiruvalluvar Statue. Walking on this bridge was one of the highlights of my trip. You can see the ocean below your feet, and it gives you a thrilling and beautiful view of the surroundings.

The whole area is very clean and well-maintained. The strong sea breeze made the environment feel fresh and relaxing. It was really peaceful to stand near the statue with the wind blowing and enjoy the sound of the waves all around. The scenery is stunning, especially the view of the three oceans — the Bay of Bengal, Arabian Sea, and Indian Ocean — meeting at this point.

The Thiruvalluvar Statue itself is grand and inspiring, honoring one of Tamil Nadu’s greatest poets and philosophers. The peaceful surroundings, combined with the majestic statue and the exciting walk on the sea bridge, created a perfect mix of nature, culture, and adventure.

If you're planning a visit to Kanyakumari, I highly recommend coming early in the morning or near sunset to fully enjoy the view, wind, and light. The sea bridge adds a new dimension to the experience — it's safe, exciting, and offers fantastic photo opportunities.

Great place, need to take government operated boats for the to and fro journey from kanykumari to the statue. It's around 80 Rs to take the boat ride. By giving 300Rs fast moving line can be utilised. Nice scenic place. Try avoiding peak noon time. There is glass bridge connecting between the statue and the meditation centre which is also an attraction.

Kanyakumari is a truly mesmerizing place where nature, history, and spirituality blend beautifully. Watching the sunrise and sunset over the ocean from the same spot is a unique and unforgettable experience. The Vivekananda Rock Memorial and Thiruvalluvar Statue are both iconic landmarks worth visiting — peaceful, inspiring, and scenic.

The confluence of the Arabian Sea, Bay of Bengal, and Indian Ocean is stunning to witness. The town is clean, the locals are warm and welcoming, and there's a calm spiritual vibe everywhere. Street food is great too, especially the fresh coconut water and local snacks.

Highly recommended for anyone looking to unwind, explore Indian culture, or just enjoy coastal beauty. I'd definitely love to return!

Visited the iconic Thiruvalluvar Statue today on 15th July 25 and it was an inspiring experience! Standing tall at 133 feet, this majestic statue honors the legendary Tamil poet and philosopher Thiruvalluvar, who gifted us the timeless Thirukkural.
The view of the endless ocean all around adds to the peaceful yet powerful atmosphere. It's not just a monument—it's a symbol of ancient wisdom, Tamil pride, and universal values.

Visiting the Thiruvalluvar statue was a really memorable experience. Standing tall against the backdrop of the ocean, the statue looks so majestic and inspiring—it almost feels like it’s watching over the waves with wisdom. The boat ride to reach the statue added to the excitement, and once there, I was amazed by the sheer size and detailed craftsmanship. Being up close made me appreciate not just the beauty but also the cultural importance behind it. The only small drawback was the crowd and a bit of waiting time, but once you’re there, it’s worth it. It’s a place that makes you pause, reflect, and feel proud of such heritage. 🌊🙏

Winds are nice. But overall it's a scam place. There is too much crowd. The queue to go back to ferry ride is too big. It's better to not go there. There is nothing tonsee there. Only the glass bridge can be a okok thing to see. But the glass is tinted and u can't see much.

I have visited Kanyakumari on 7th July for the first time. It is a mesmerising destination of Tamil Nadu.  A 133 foot tall Thiruvalluvar statue worth to watch. Separate building for Vivekanandha rock memorial Hall. Here you can sit and do meditation. Glass bridge is to reach Thiruvalluvar statue is the one of the amazing experience  we can ever had. Very thrilling experience. You can take videos when you are walking on the glass bridge. It’s looks like we are walking on the water. If you reach close to Thiruvalluvar statue it’s difficult to take photo near the statue because of the height of the statue photo won’t cover the full statue. But entrance itself you can see the front view of the Thiruvalllivar statue.

Eknath Ranadeji who founded the  Vivekananda Memorial Hall, Kanyakumari,  suggested that a statue of Thiruvalluvar be erected on a nearby rock and gave the full plan, map and estimate to the then Chief Minister M. Karunanidhi .
A boat called a 'Pantoon' was purchased from Kochi to transport the stones for the construction of the statue .
On January 1, 2000, the then Chief Minister M. Karunanidhi inaugurated the statue.

One can reach here from the Vivekananda Rock through a glass bridge.

Thiruvalluvar is a Tamil poet who composed the Tamil literature called Thirukural.
His statue has been erected on a rock 30 feet above the water level where the three seas meet.

The Swami Vivekananda Memorial Hall has been erected on a rock in the middle of the Kanyakumari sea and the 133-foot-tall Thiruvalluvar statue on another rock nearby.
The Silver Jubilee is being celebrated to mark the completion of 25 years since the installation of the Thiruvalluvar statue.

A glass fibre bridge has been built to connect these two at a cost of Rs. 37 crores.
This was opened to the public on 30 th December 2024.
Thousands of people walk on this glass bridge and enjoy the beauty of the sea before reaching the Thiruvalluvar Statue area.
Tourists  went from the boat house to Vivekananda Rock walked through the glass fiber bridge and visited the Thiruvalluvar statue.

sources.snippet: Other major travel places at Kanyakumari include a host of beautiful beaches including Sothavilai Beach, Sanguthurai Beach and of course the main Kanyakumari Beach. Play with the waters of the ocean, take a stroll on the beaches as you witness the beautiful sun setting across the horizon-the beautiful beaches of Kanyakumari will always fill you with a sense of wonder. Away from the coastline Kanyakumari boasts of several other attractions for visiting including waterfalls, temples, churches, museums and historical monuments.

sources.snippet: Located at the confluence of 3 oceans, Kanyakumari beach lies at the southernmost tip of India and visiting this special tourist place of Kanyakumari in itself is a resplendent feeling. Besides, the stunning beach is famous for its spectacular vista of sunrise and sunset. Being the meeting point of three oceans, the tides at the beach are high and turbulent but that is not deterring enough as the geographical positioning is a high point for all the travellers.

reviews.reviewText:
📣Kanyakumari Amman Temple: 4:30 AM to 12:30 PM, and again from 4:00 PM to 8:00 PM.
Vivekananda Rock Memorial: 8:00 AM to 4:00 PM, with ferry services operating during those hours.
Padmanabhapuram Palace: 9:00 AM to 12:30 PM, and again from 2:00 PM to 4:30 PM.
Vattakottai Fort: 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM.

Boats to the Vivekananda Rock Memorial in Kanyakumari typically operate from 8:00 AM to 4:00 PM. The ferry ride takes about 30 minutes to reach the memorial.
The visiting timing of Saint Thiruvalluvar Statue is from 8 AM to 4 PM. The charge for ferry services from the shore to the statue are Rs. 20 per person

Pricing in Kanyakumari
Ferry Type	Price Range (INR)
Standard M2M Ferries	500 - 800
Luxury M2M Ferries	1500 - 2500
Roro Ferry	700 - 1200
Ajanta Ferry	600 - 1000

The best time to visit Kanyakumari is between October to February as the temperature during these months usually drops and ranges between 20-30 degree Celsius.

Kanyakumari is open to visitors throughout the day. Specific opening and closing times apply to various attractions, but the general rule is that the main sites are open from early morning until late afternoon/early evening.

The statue is built as per Indian architectural styles, and is hollow inside. However, tourists are allowed to climb only up to the foot of the statue. Along with the Vivekananda Rock Memorial, the statue attracts millions of tourists annually and is one of the must-visit spots in your trip to Tamil Nadu.

Watching the sunrise at Kanyakumari Beach is truly breathtaking – a must-see experience. However, the beach gets extremely crowded on weekends, making it a bit difficult to enjoy peacefully. Unfortunately, the beach was quite unclean and dirty, which took away from the overall experience.

Kanyakumari Beach is a mesmerizing destination where the blue waters meet the land’s edge. With the sea on three sides, it offers breathtaking views, making it a unique coastal experience. The beach is safe for bathing, allowing visitors to enjoy the refreshing waves. Changing rooms are available, ensuring convenience for travelers. As the southernmost tip of India, this location holds special significance and provides a spectacular horizon where the ocean seems endless. A must-visit spot for anyone seeking beauty and tranquility by the shore.

Kanyakumari Beach offers a breathtaking view where the Bay of Bengal, Arabian Sea, and Indian Ocean meet. The sunrise and sunset here are magical, especially from the View Tower and near the Vivekananda Rock Memorial. The beach is rocky, not ideal for swimming, but perfect for peaceful walks, photography, and soaking in the spiritual and scenic atmosphere.

Nice beach.it was raining..it was a long wait to get ticket for the ferry to reach the statue..if you are not patient enough to wait in a queue it's better to go for a 300 Rs ticket it's like direct entrance but the same ferry for evebody..but once you the glass bridge it is so good..
Witnessing the sunrise in Kanyakumari was truly a soul-stirring experience. Finally stepping into the glass bridge was a great experience of thrill and beauty 💙. Everyone should experience this!!!

“Kanyakumari Beach is truly a special place where you can witness the meeting point of the Arabian Sea, Bay of Bengal, and Indian Ocean. The view is breathtaking, especially during sunrise and sunset when the sky lights up with beautiful colors. The beach area is clean and has a calm atmosphere with plenty of spots to sit and enjoy the sea breeze. From here, you also get a clear view of the Vivekananda Rock Memorial and Thiruvalluvar Statue. A must-visit destination in Kanyakumari for nature lovers, photographers, and anyone who wants to enjoy a peaceful seaside experience.”

The most beautiful destination with high footfall. But infrastructure flop. Cannot find  a clean public comfort station, expanded parking facility, water kiosks, waiting areas etc. Instead can experience severe extortion of tourist by locals. Car owners have to pay at check post and parking area simultaneously for touring along beach side. Parking big problem as we have to bribe for allowing parking in private places and streets. The most popular rock structured shrine kanyakumari devi temple is found kept in a dilapidated state without proper access and affairs inside mismanaged. The vivekananda rock, thiruvalluvar statue, glass bridge, laser shows, tirupati temple, sucheendram temple, kumarakovil temple, onshore mupanthal windmill, thovala flower cultivations etc are some of the places to visit here. Hotels and restaurants found unhygienic without food safety inspections. Renovated ttdc somewhat good for food and stay. Street vendors occupying public spaces in an inconsiderate manner is affecting the beauty and charm and ambience of kanyakumari. Just projecting sun rise and sun set can't do with tourism  alone. Establishing world class activities and amenities is the need of the hour for keeping kanyakumari into a world class travel destination as the new highway is going to pave way for good access.

reviews.reviewText: I visited this church recently. It is very beautiful and very nice. The church is located at the sea shore near Kanyakumari. You can definitely visit the historic place and enjoy some peaceful time there ❣️

A serene oasis! Our Lady of Ransom Shrine is a haven of peace and spirituality. The cleanliness and ambiance inside the church are truly uplifting. A wonderful place for reflection and prayer. Highly recommended for those seeking solace and tranquility.✨🌟

Visited on today morning. A small thatched church was upgraded in 1700 when a big church of Roman architecture was constructed. A statue of Mother Mary was created in the 16th century derived in Rome. The statue, clad with a sari, was placed in the centre of a golden altar . Statues of St. Joseph and St. Francis Xavier were placed in the right side and left side respectively

This beautiful church stands tall at Kanyakumari. Gothic architecture. It's visible from the Vivekananda memorial rock as well. They conduct Tamil masses. The church doesn't have a huge compound wall unlike the other churches. It is right amidst the houses around and at the heart of the town, very close to the ocean. Well maintained. Not a lot of benches to be seated, people were seated on the floor but there is seating available as well.
Visited the chruch recently in the early morning at Kanyakumari. It is very close to sunrise view point. The architecture is very beautiful. Gives peace of mind.

It's was very hot outside premise, but as soon as we entered in the shrine, we find the calmness...the structure of the shrine was impressive, large area for gatherings at outside. And you can see the heat waves on our faces.
2017.

reviews.reviewText: Amazing temple!! You need to pay anyone anything. Just walk in to have a blessed darshan!!. Men will have to open their shirts. The temple is old, and the idol is amazing. The nose ring, which is the highlight, shines in all glory!! History has it that ships used to steer to coast seeing the shine of the nose ring!! It's really worth visiting. Views from behind temples are also good!

The temple is about 1 to 2 km from the railway station—easy to reach by walk or auto. Don’t miss the beautiful sunrise at Kanyakumari—it’s a must-see!

The deity here is very powerful and divine. For male devotees, shirts or T-shirts are not allowed inside the temple. Only dhoti or pants are allowed, and the upper body must be uncovered.

There are both free and paid darshan options available. For fresh-up, there are many clock rooms and fresh-up rooms nearby. No need to spend much on rooms—basic fresh-up facilities are available for just ₹30.

A peaceful and powerful place to visit with spiritual energy all around.

Kanyakumari, the southernmost tip of India, is a place where land, sea, and sky converge in breathtaking harmony. Renowned for its stunning sunrise views over the Bay of Bengal, it offers a serene spectacle that draws travelers from around the world. The Vivekananda Rock Memorial stands as a tribute to spiritual reflection and national pride, while the ancient Bhagavathi Amman Temple, dedicated to the goddess Kanyakumari, adds a layer of historical and cultural depth to this coastal gem.

Amman Temple is a must-visit for anyone in Kanyakumari. The temple is beautifully maintained and has a serene, spiritual atmosphere. The early morning visit is highly recommended to avoid crowds and to experience the tranquility of the place.
I visited during the early hours, just in time for the Arti   and it was incredibly peaceful. The divine energy of the temple combined with the soft chants and cool morning breeze made for a truly spiritual experience. The temple is dedicated to Goddess Kanyakumari, and the structure is magnificent, reflecting both historical significance and spiritual beauty. The temple complex is clean, and the surroundings are calming.

reviews.reviewText: A fine memorial museum decicated to The Father of Our Nation , located on a beautiful seashore which he had visited and written about . After his cremation, a part of his  ashes too were consigned  to the ocean at this place . The huge hall is a very peaceful place to sit in silence and think about the life and teachings of this great man . Many rare photos from his life are exhibited as also  his sayings . Outside , we find an installation with statues of Gandhi and Kamaraja against a backdrop of gushing waves .  A must visit for all . Children, especially, need to be taken here and told about Gandhiji’s greatness.

During our visit to the Mahatma Gandhi Mandapam in Kanyakumari, we were struck by its architectural beauty and historical significance. The mandapam, built to honor Mahatma Gandhi, is situated near the confluence of the Arabian Sea, the Bay of Bengal, and the Indian Ocean, offering breathtaking views of the surrounding waters.

The structure is designed to allow sunlight to fall on the exact spot where Gandhi's ashes were kept, symbolizing his enlightenment and teachings. Inside, the serene atmosphere provides a space for reflection on Gandhi's life and principles.

Visitors have noted the cleanliness and maintenance of the site, as well as the informative displays that offer insights into Gandhi's journey and philosophy. The mandapam serves as both a tourist attraction and a place of homage, drawing individuals interested in India's history and the legacy of the Mahatma.

Overall, the Mahatma Gandhi Mandapam is a must-visit landmark in Kanyakumari, offering a blend of architectural elegance, historical depth, and scenic beauty.

A picturesque mausoleum of sorts right by the shore. It's a monument dedicated to the life and ethos of MK Gandhi. There's no entry fee, but you will have to pay a small fee at the footwear stand.

Inside, you'll witness an array of memorabilia from his early days as a barrister in South Africa all the way to his pivotal role in India's Independence. At the Memorial's center, you can see the spot where his ashes were kept before immersion.

Worth the visit if you're touring the town. You also have great views of the shoreline outside.

reviews.reviewText:
The Gandhi Memorial near Triveni is a significant tourist attraction, holding historical importance as the site where Mahatma Gandhi's ashes were kept before his final rites. The memorial beautifully chronicles Gandhi's journey from Porbandir to his final days, highlighting his pivotal role in India's freedom movement.

This iconic structure proudly showcases India's rich cultural heritage, offering insights into Gandhi's teachings, philosophy, and service to the nation. The 79-foot-high central building symbolizes Gandhi's age at the time of his passing.

A striking feature of the memorial is its architectural design, where the ceiling's opening allows sunlight to illuminate the spot where Gandhi's ashes were kept on his birth anniversary, October 2nd. The rooftop offers breathtaking panoramic views of the surrounding ocean.

Best of all, entry to the memorial is free, making it accessible to all who wish to pay their respects and learn about India's history.

Proudly upholding the rich cultural heritage of India, the Gandhi Memorial offers a clear picture of the teachings, philosophy, ideal and services rendered by Mahatma Gandhi for the country.

The central area of the building has been built in a way that stands 79 feet high, symbolizing the age of Mahatma Gandhi at the time of his demise.

The most striking feature here is the ceiling of the building. It has an opening that has been built in such a way that on every 2nd October, (birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi) rays of Sun falls exactly on the spot where his ashes were kept.

The roof of the memorial gives a beautiful panoramic view of the ocean around.

Entry to the memorial is free..

So, I heard about the amazing Kamaraja, and I really wanted to know more about him, you know?
The Kamarajar Mandapam was built to remember Mr. Kamaraj, who was the chief minister of Tamil Nadu for 13 years. He was famous for being simple and honest.
It's a great place to go, it's kept up really well, and it's super peaceful. It's a good spot for meditating, too. Plus, it's the best place to see where the rivers meet the sea and the beach. They have photos that show his life story, which is really cool. It's all organized nicely, and the surroundings are nice. It's a good place to bring the kids so they can learn about awesome people.
You don't have to pay to get in but the uncle who tells the stories about this will ask some money.

Another monument Kamarajar Manimandapam was raised and dedicated to Late. Sri. Kamarajar, The freedom fighter, Former Chief minister of Tamil Nadu, President of Indian National Congress. He was popularly known as Black Gandhi among the masses and king maker during congress regime.  He is still called by all as “Perunthalaivar”. He played vital roles in the administration of TamilNadu, by introducing education for down trodden and also started the Noon Meal scheme for the students to encourage education. Development activities like Dams and Industries in Tamilnadu took place during his rule. This monument was constructed where his ashes were kept here for public to pay homage before immersion into the sea.

Visting Hours -7 AM To 7 PM .

Kamarajar actively participated in the Indian independence movement, working alongside other prominent leaders to fight for India's freedom from British rule.

Like many other freedom fighters, Kamarajar faced imprisonment for his political activities against the British.

After India gained independence, Kamarajar continued to serve the nation as a politician. He became the Chief Minister of Madras State (now Tamil Nadu) and later served as the President of the Indian National Congress.

He is also known for his influence in Indian politics, particularly his role in elevating Lal Bahadur Shastri and Indira Gandhi to the position of Prime Minister, earning him the title "Kingmaker".

Visited on today morning it is situated near Gandhi Mandapam, offering visitors a chance to explore multiple historical sites in close proximity.  Inside, the photographic exhibits provide a comprehensive overview of Kamaraj's life, his contributions to India's political landscape, and his dedication to public service.

Kanniyakumari, the country's southernmost tip offers a diverse array of attractions, such as beaches, temples, museums, and more. One must-see attraction is the Kamarajar Manimandapam in Kanyakumari, a significant historical site dedicated to Kamarajar, a freedom fighter and former Chief Minister of Tamil Nadu.

The picturesque town of Kanyakumari was chosen by the government as the final resting place for Kamaraj's ashes, allowing people to pay their respects before the ashes are submerged in the sea, in consideration of Kingmaker Kamaraj's popularity.

Visiting Time 7Am To 7Pm

We felt a wave of disappointment wash over us. As we approached the mandapam, we became increasingly cautious, especially when we noticed a man lurking nearby, persistently asking for money. This unexpected encounter was frustrating, as we were unaware of his intentions before stepping inside. During our visit to the Kamarajar Mani Mandapam in Kanyakumari, we were deeply moved by the tribute to Shri K. Kamaraj, a revered freedom fighter and former Chief Minister of Tamil Nadu. Known as the "Black Gandhi" and "Perunthalaivar," Kamaraj was instrumental in introducing the free midday meal scheme in schools in 1962, encouraging education among the underprivileged.

The memorial is situated near the Triveni Sangam, adjacent to the Gandhi Mandapam, offering visitors a chance to explore multiple historical sites in close proximity.  Inside, the photographic exhibits provide a comprehensive overview of Kamaraj's life, his contributions to India's political landscape, and his dedication to public service.

The architecture of the mandapam is notable, blending traditional Dravidian elements with contemporary design, reminiscent of a gopuram found in South Indian temples.  The serene ambiance of the memorial offers a space for reflection on the enduring legacy of a leader who prioritized education and social welfare.

Overall, the Kamarajar Mani Mandapam stands as a significant landmark in Kanyakumari, honoring a leader whose vision and efforts have left a lasting impact on Tamil Nadu and India as a whole.

Kamarajar, as Chief Minister of Madras State (now Tamil Nadu), oversaw the construction of numerous dams during his tenure. While the exact number is not specified, several significant dams were built during his period, including the Parambikulam Dam, Lower Bhavani, Krishnagiri, Mani Muthuar, Cauvery delta, Aarani River, Vaigai Dam, Amravathi, Sathanur, Pullambadi, and Neyaru Dams.

sources.snippet: The temple to Kanyakumari or Bagawathi Amman is one among the 108 Shakthi peethas and was built around 3000 years ago, with the idol of Kanya Kumari installed by Sage Parasurama. The sanctum is lit only with oil lamps in the midst of which we find the idol of Kanya Kumari standing upright, with a glittering diamond pin encrusted with rubies, on her nose. According to legends, the sparkle from her nose pin was so bright that the ships sailing at night thought it was the signal from the Light House and ended up getting ship wrecked.

An ideally located helical ramp tower that offers spectacular panoramic views of the shoreline and cityscape. You can catch both sunrise and sunset from here due to the high vantage point it offers... if you're okay taking your shots along with the crowd that flocks here during those times.

The tower has an entry fee, ₹15 per head. Overall, great place for some idyllic views of India's costal frontier.

The tower is renowned for its breathtaking sunrise and sunset views. Here you can view 360-degree of Kanyakumari's coastline is truly mesmerizing. A must visit spot for those exploring Kanniyakumari's natural beauties.

“Great spot to enjoy sunrise and sunset in Kanyakumari. The spiral tower gives a clear view of the Vivekananda Rock, Thiruvalluvar statue, and the sea meeting point. Very affordable entry and worth a visit!”
ticket rate is 15/- for (adult)

To view the sea and the entire region from an elevated level, this is a sure to visit while at Kanya Kumari. A nominal fee is required to pay for entry.

placeMetadata.name: Government Museum, Kanniyakumari

sources.snippet: The Government Museum is a must-see on your visit to Kanyakumari. There are ancient sculptures of Gods, Kings and poets, ancient coins, wood carvings, botanical and zoological specimens and musical instruments, a temple chariot made of whale bones from Manavalakurichi, objects used by tribal people and a Travancore Gallery with memorabilia of the Travancore rulers. The Government Museum is located on the Beach Road, about 1.2 km from the Kanyakumari Railway Station.
sources.shortName: Tourist Places To Visit In Kanyakumari (2025)

sources.snippet: Presenting a rich collection of artifacts, including coins, wood carvings, Tribal objects and bronze sculptures, Government Museum is an ideal place to visit and get a glimpse into eras gone by. There are also displays of various kinds of crafts related to South Indian Temples. One can also see zoological and botanical specimens at this museum, including whale-bones, brought from Manavalakurichi town of Kanyakumari.

Visitors can also explore zoological and botanical specimens including whale bones from Manavalakurichi town.

placeMetadata.name: Sunset View Point

sources.snippet: Kanyakumari is famous around the world for its most enchanting sunset and sunrise and what could be a better spot than Sunset View Point. Witness the Sun melting down in the horizon from the Sunset View Point which is reckoned as one of the topmost attractions of Kanyakumari. Apart from the spectacular view of sunrise and sunset at the confluence of three water bodies, one can savour the tranquil vibes of this serenading spot which is thronged by photographers and tourists from all over the world.

sources.snippet: Sunset View Point is one of the most famous places for photographers in Kanyakumari. It is really amazing to watch the sun going down into the ocean and behind Thiruvalluvar statue with Vivekananda rock memorial on it in front.

Location: It is close to the Triveni Sangam (confluence point) and the Vivekananda Rock Memorial area, easily accessible from the main town.
•	Experience: Visitors gather here every evening to witness the breathtaking sunset, where the sun appears to sink into the horizon, painting the sky with shades of orange, pink, purple, and gold.
•	Special Features: On clear days, you can even spot the silhouette of the Vivekananda Rock Memorial and the Thiruvalluvar Statue against the colorful sky, making it a perfect spot for photography.
•	Best Time to Visit: October to March offers the clearest skies, though sunsets are spectacular throughout the year.
•	Cultural Vibe: The place often has a lively yet peaceful vibe, with locals and tourists enjoying the cool breeze, the sound of crashing waves, and the serenity of the ocean view.

Sunset Point in Kanyakumari is a breathtakingly beautiful spot where the day ends in a blaze of colors over the vast ocean horizon. As the sun dips into the sea, the sky transforms into a stunning canvas of orange, pink, and gold—making it a truly magical sight to behold. The unique location, where three seas meet, adds to the surreal atmosphere and makes the sunset here unlike any other in India.

The area draws a good crowd in the evening, with tourists and locals alike gathering to witness nature’s spectacle. Despite the popularity, it’s easy to find a quiet moment to soak in the view. It’s the perfect place to unwind, reflect, and simply enjoy the beauty of the present moment. Don’t forget to bring your camera—the Kanyakumari sunset is unforgettable.

The Sunset Point in Kanyakumari offers some of the most stunning ocean views you’ll find  Unfortunately, I missed the sunset because it was a bit cloudy on the day I visited, but the place still offers a wonderful experience. When the skies are clear, it's supposed to be an amazing spot to watch the sun dip into the ocean.  Arrive early to secure a good spot and enjoy the view before the crowd gathers.

The Kanyakumari sunset is a breathtaking spectacle where the sun melts into the horizon, painting the sky in shades of gold, crimson, and purple. Surrounded by the meeting of three seas, the view feels spiritual and timeless, leaving travelers humbled by nature’s artistry and the calm it brings.

Great spot to watch the sunset. Kanyakumari offers one of the most amazing sunrise and sunset experiences. It is recommended to arrive around 5:30 PM so that you can find a good spot before the place gets crowded.

One pro tip: if you are taking a time-lapse of the sunrise or sunset, keep the FPS at least 120x to clearly capture the movement of the sun. I have attached the sunset timelapse taken at 60x.

After enjoying the sunset, don’t miss trying banana bhajji while watching the ocean.

placeMetadata.name: Gandhi Mandapam

sources.snippet: Gandhi Mandapam is one of the most respected places to visit in Kanyakumari. It is at this place the ashes of our Father of Nation Gandhi's ashes were kept before immersing into the sea. The mandapam is a memorial constructed in 1956 in the remembrance of the Great Leader of our country.
sources.shortName: 25 Places to Visit in Kanyakumari, Tourist Places & Attractions

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Gandhi Mandapam, located in Kanyakumari, is a significant memorial dedicated to Mahatma Gandhi. Situated close to the shore, it marks the exact spot where his ashes were placed for public tribute before being dissolved in the Triveni Sangam. The memorial houses rare photographs of Gandhi with prominent Western figures and is a top tourist attraction in Kanyakumari.

placeMetadata.name: Kanniyakumari view

sources.snippet: Priceless sunrises and sunsets, on Kanyakumari's watery horizon, are among the finest in India. Sunrise, alongside the Thiruvalluvar statue, is arguably the most majestic of the two. However, sunsets are particularly special on full moon nights, when the moon rises from the sea opposite the setting sun at about the same time.

Sunrise Point in Kanyakumari offers a breathtaking view of the sun rising over the confluence of the Bay of Bengal, the Arabian Sea, and the Indian Ocean. To fully enjoy this serene experience, it's advisable to arrive early, as the area tends to get crowded with visitors eager to witness the first light of day. The sight of the sun illuminating landmarks like the Vivekananda Rock Memorial and the Thiruvalluvar Statue adds to the charm of the moment. Despite the early hour, the peaceful ambiance and stunning visuals make it a must-visit spot in Kanyakumari.

Kanyakumari Pier is a breathtaking spot where you can truly experience the beauty of the southernmost tip of India. The vast ocean stretching endlessly, with waves crashing against the pier, creates a mesmerizing view. It’s a great place to take a peaceful walk, enjoy the sea breeze, and soak in the panoramic sights.

Sunrise and sunset here are absolutely magical, with the sky painted in vibrant hues. You can also see fishing boats in the distance, adding to the charm of the place. The pier is not very crowded, making it a perfect spot for photography and quiet reflection.

If you’re visiting Kanyakumari, this place is a must-visit for its serene and scenic vibe!

Standing at the edge of the pier, you can see the vast endless ocean, making it a surreal experience.

Unlike the main tourist spots, the pier is relatively calm, making it a great place to unwind and enjoy nature.

One should be careful of the strong wind, especially near the edges of the pier. The breeze is refreshing, but at times, it can be quite powerful, making it important to hold onto your belongings and stay cautious while enjoying the breathtaking views

Not ideal for the elderly to walk on. I wouldn't strongly recommend taking children here.

Undoubtedly the best place to see the sunrise in Kanyakumari. Visited here with the friends and the experience was beyond the expectations. headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we’re always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Kanyakumari, the southernmost tip of India, is a mesmerizing blend of natural beauty and rich cultural heritage. With its stunning coastline where the Indian Ocean, Bay of Bengal, and Arabian Sea converge, this vibrant destination offers countless opportunities for capturing breathtaking photographs. From the iconic Vivekananda Rock Memorial standing proudly against the waves to the majestic Thiruvalluvar Statue rising high on its island, every corner of Kanyakumari tells a story waiting to be captured through your lens.

As you explore this enchanting locale, you'll discover hidden gems like the serene Sunset View Point, where the sun dips below the horizon in a spectacular display of colors. The intricate architecture of the Mahatma Gandhi Mandapam and the tranquil ambiance of the Kanya Kumari Amman Temple provide perfect backdrops for your travel memories. Whether you're a seasoned photographer or just looking to snap some beautiful moments, Kanyakumari is a treasure trove of picturesque spots that will inspire your creativity and leave you with unforgettable memories.

placeMetadata.name: Kanyakumari Beach

sources.snippet: The sound of waves you get to hear on this beach, you can’t find anywhere else. The place remains flooded with beach lovers every day. But swimming and surfing are not allowed here as the sea can be rough.
sources.shortName: Kanyakumari: An incredible beach town in Tamil Nadu

sources.snippet: Located in the southernmost part of India, Kanyakumari beach with its beautiful hue-changing beaches, the confluence of three water bodies: Bay of Bengal, Indian Ocean, and the Arabian Sea. Miraculously, here you can see that the water of three seas does not mix, you can distinguish between the turquoise blue, deep blue, and sea green waters of the three seas, though the colors keep changing with the season and the day's weather. The beach is not conducive to swim or surf as the water as the sea is rough and the beach is rocky.To enjoy the best view, you can visit the Triveni Sangam point and climb up the famous lighthouse watchtower to entirely take in its beauty.
sources.shortName: Kanyakumari Beach, Kanyakumari (2024) - Images, Timings

sources.snippet: Other major travel places at Kanyakumari include a host of beautiful beaches including Sothavilai Beach, Sanguthurai Beach and of course the main Kanyakumari Beach. Play with the waters of the ocean, take a stroll on the beaches as you witness the beautiful sun setting across the horizon-the beautiful beaches of Kanyakumari will always fill you with a sense of wonder. Away from the coastline Kanyakumari boasts of several other attractions for visiting including waterfalls, temples, churches, museums and historical monuments.
sources.shortName: Kanyakumari Tourism- Best Places to Visit in Kanyakumari

sources.snippet: The Kanyakumari sunrise is the predominant reason why people come here. While sunrise at a beach is always splendid, there is something very magical about the sun’s first rays touching the waters of all the three oceans that surround the Indian Peninsula- the Bay of Bengal, the Indian Ocean and the Arabian Sea. The three distinct shades of the waters of the three oceans can be witnessed here and it is quite an experience.
sources.shortName: Beauty Sightseeing, Shopping & Best Time to Explore

sources.snippet: The best time to visit Kanyakumari Beach is in the winter season from October to February when the region experiences pleasant and calming climatic conditions. This is the peak season to visit the beach as the weather remains comfortable for outdoor activities. There are no adventure sports that take place here, however, tourists can spend quality time here and enjoy the bliss of the tranquil tourist destination.
sources.shortName: Kanyakumari Beach | Best Time to Visit

sources.snippet: Kanyakumari Amman Temple : A temple for Devi Kanyakumari, corresponding to the legend of the coastal city and its beach, has been built dedicated to the young and fiery goddess. The deity is smaller than any usual South Indian idol, but its diamond nose ring is said to be so bright and radiant that distant ships often mistake it for a lighthouse's beam of light.
sources.shortName: Kanyakumari Beach, Beaches in India

sources.snippet: Kanyakumari beach, located in the southernmost part of India, is the meeting point of three bodies of water - the Arabian Sea, the Indian Ocean, and the Bay of Bengal. Despite the fact that the water of these three bodies does not mix, you will be able to distinguish between their colours, though they change with the season and the weather of the day.
sources.shortName: 18 Beautiful Beaches in Tamil Nadu That You Should Visit

sources.snippet: Kanyakumari Beach, situated at the southernmost tip of India where the Arabian Sea, Bay of Bengal, and Indian Ocean meet, is a picturesque destination known for its stunning views of the sunrise and sunset. The beach is surrounded by rocky shores and has a vibrant atmosphere, attracting tourists from all over the world.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Kanyakumari Beach, situated at the southernmost tip of the Indian Peninsula, offers breathtaking views of sunsets and moonrises over the confluence of three seas: the Indian Ocean, Bay of Bengal, and Arabian Sea. The rocky shoreline provides a picturesque setting for leisurely strolls while listening to the unique sound of waves. Visitors can savor local cuisine and explore nearby temples. It is best to visit during December and January to avoid extreme heat and humidity.

reviews.reviewText:
📣Kanyakumari Amman Temple: 4:30 AM to 12:30 PM, and again from 4:00 PM to 8:00 PM.
Vivekananda Rock Memorial: 8:00 AM to 4:00 PM, with ferry services operating during those hours.
Padmanabhapuram Palace: 9:00 AM to 12:30 PM, and again from 2:00 PM to 4:30 PM.
Vattakottai Fort: 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM.

Boats to the Vivekananda Rock Memorial in Kanyakumari typically operate from 8:00 AM to 4:00 PM. The ferry ride takes about 30 minutes to reach the memorial.
The visiting timing of Saint Thiruvalluvar Statue is from 8 AM to 4 PM. The charge for ferry services from the shore to the statue are Rs. 20 per person

Luxury M2M Ferries	1500 - 2500

The best time to visit Kanyakumari is between October to February as the temperature during these months usually drops and ranges between 20-30 degree Celsius.

Kanyakumari is open to visitors throughout the day. Specific opening and closing times apply to various attractions, but the general rule is that the main sites are open from early morning until late afternoon/early evening.

The statue is built as per Indian architectural styles, and is hollow inside. However, tourists are allowed to climb only up to the foot of the statue. Along with the Vivekananda Rock Memorial, the statue attracts millions of tourists annually and is one of the must-visit spots in your trip to Tamil Nadu.

Watching the sunrise at Kanyakumari Beach is truly breathtaking – a must-see experience. However, the beach gets extremely crowded on weekends, making it a bit difficult to enjoy peacefully. Unfortunately, the beach was quite unclean and dirty, which took away from the overall experience.

Kanyakumari Beach is a mesmerizing destination where the blue waters meet the land’s edge. With the sea on three sides, it offers breathtaking views, making it a unique coastal experience. The beach is safe for bathing, allowing visitors to enjoy the refreshing waves. Changing rooms are available, ensuring convenience for travelers. As the southernmost tip of India, this location holds special significance and provides a spectacular horizon where the ocean seems endless. A must-visit spot for anyone seeking beauty and tranquility by the shore.

Kanyakumari Beach offers a breathtaking view where the Bay of Bengal, Arabian Sea, and Indian Ocean meet. The sunrise and sunset here are magical, especially from the View Tower and near the Vivekananda Rock Memorial. The beach is rocky, not ideal for swimming, but perfect for peaceful walks, photography, and soaking in the spiritual and scenic atmosphere.

Nice beach.it was raining..it was a long wait to get ticket for the ferry to reach the statue..if you are not patient enough to wait in a queue it's better to go for a 300 Rs ticket it's like direct entrance but the same ferry for evebody..but once you the glass bridge it is so good..
Witnessing the sunrise in Kanyakumari was truly a soul-stirring experience. Finally stepping into the glass bridge was a great experience of thrill and beauty 💙. Everyone should experience this!!!

“Kanyakumari Beach is truly a special place where you can witness the meeting point of the Arabian Sea, Bay of Bengal, and Indian Ocean. The view is breathtaking, especially during sunrise and sunset when the sky lights up with beautiful colors. The beach area is clean and has a calm atmosphere with plenty of spots to sit and enjoy the sea breeze. From here, you also get a clear view of the Vivekananda Rock Memorial and Thiruvalluvar Statue. A must-visit destination in Kanyakumari for nature lovers, photographers, and anyone who wants to enjoy a peaceful seaside experience.”

The most beautiful destination with high footfall. But infrastructure flop. Cannot find  a clean public comfort station, expanded parking facility, water kiosks, waiting areas etc. Instead can experience severe extortion of tourist by locals. Car owners have to pay at check post and parking area simultaneously for touring along beach side. Parking big problem as we have to bribe for allowing parking in private places and streets. Establishing world class activities and amenities is the need of the hour for keeping kanyakumari into a world class travel destination as the new highway is going to pave way for good access.

placeMetadata.name: Vivekananda Rock Memorial

sources.snippet: Dedicated to Swami Vivekananda, a religious reformer, the Vivekananda Rock Memorial is one of the most popular tourist attraction in Kanyakumari. Covering an area of six acres, the rock memorial is situated at an island a few metres into the sea and positioned at a level of 17 metres above the sea level. Apart from that, a statue of celebrated Tamil poet, Thiruvalluvar, standing tall, almost at the confluence of the three seas, is a major tourist place.

sources.snippet: The magnificent Vivekananda Rock Memorial is located on a small island off Kanyakumari. It has the picturesque Indian Ocean in its backdrop. It is situated on one of the two adjacent rocks projecting (Read More)out of the Lakshadweep Sea and comprises of the 'Shripada Mandapam' and the 'Vivekananda Mandapam'.Vivekananda Rock Memorial is located at about 500 meters east of the mainland of Vavathurai in Kanyakumari and can be accessed by regular ferries.

sources.snippet: Vivekananda Rock Memorial : A rock formation cut off from the mainland, around 500 metres away in the Indian Ocean is famous as the place where the great saint Swami Vivekananda set his foot in 1892 after travelling the entirety of the country on foot. The Vivekanand Rock Memorial is also famous as the place where Devi Kanyakumari had actually practised her penance for Lord Shiva standing on one foot.

reviews.reviewText: Good tourist spot. Price was reasonable. Week days were not crowded. Boat service was good but the life jacket could have maintained properly. The glass bridge was mesmerizing.

Vivekananda Rock Memorial – Beautiful, But Be Prepared

The Vivekananda Rock Memorial is undoubtedly a serene and inspiring place, rich in history and spiritual significance. The view from the rock, surrounded by the endless sea and with the mainland in the distance, is truly breathtaking. It’s a powerful spot where you can reflect and feel deeply connected to nature and Swami Vivekananda’s legacy.

However, the experience getting there was less than ideal. Despite purchasing the ₹300 ferry ticket, we still had to stand in a long, exhausting queue under the scorching sun, with minimal shade or crowd management. It was quite frustrating, especially considering the premium ticket.

Additionally, there’s a separate entrance fee for the temple once you reach the rock, which felt a bit excessive after already paying for the ferry ride. The heat and waiting time took away from the peacefulness we were hoping for.

Tips:

Carry a hat, sunglasses, and water — the sun can be relentless.
Try to visit early in the morning to avoid both the heat and long queues.
Be mentally prepared for the wait, even with a higher-priced ticket.
It’s a must-see spot for its spiritual and scenic value, but a bit of planning (and patience) is necessary to truly enjoy it.

The very sight of Vivekananda Rock from a distance fills you with a deep sense of peace and awe. Once you arrive, be prepared for a wait — even on weekdays, the queue can take around 45 minutes. You can choose between ₹100 or ₹300 tickets depending on your preference, but whichever you choose, the journey is well worth it.

Once you’re there, the calm of the rock, the spiritual energy of the place, the stunning architecture of the memorial, and the majestic Tiruvalluvar statue leave a lasting impression. The glass bridge adds a unique touch to the experience.

Note: There are no food stalls on the premises, so plan your visit after a hearty breakfast or lunch. Free drinking water is available, and there’s a small shop where you can buy books and souvenirs to take a part of the experience home.

A must-visit for those seeking serenity, inspiration, and a connection with India’s spiritual legacy.

Vivekananda Rock memorial is a neatly maintained spot to visit. We need to take the ferry to visit. The ferry service will start around 8 AM in the morning and there will be a long fast moving queue for a 100 rs ticket and for a 300 rs ticket the queue will be very less. But the long queue itself will move faster. In a single trip they'll take around 80+ people i guess. So the queue will move fast. 300 rs ticket ppl will have the first priority to board on the ferry but while returning the 300 rs ticket won't work. All 100 and 300 will have to wait in the same queue to board the ferry to return to the mainland.

Vivekananda Rock Memorial, located off the coast of Kanyakumari, is a truly serene and awe-inspiring destination. Perched on a rocky island where the Arabian Sea, Bay of Bengal, and Indian Ocean converge, the memorial offers a breathtaking panoramic view of the endless blue waters. The structure itself, dedicated to Swami Vivekananda, is a blend of spiritual energy and architectural beauty.

A must-visit spiritual and scenic marvel!
Vivekananda Rock Memorial is truly awe-inspiring—located right at the confluence of three seas, the view is absolutely breathtaking. The ferry ride adds to the charm, and the peaceful meditation hall (Dhyana Mandapam) offers a serene escape from the noise of daily life. The architecture is elegant, and the energy here is powerful. Best visited during sunrise or sunset for an unforgettable experience

A must-visit iconic place in Kanyakumari! Located on a small rocky island surrounded by the sea, this memorial is dedicated to Swami Vivekananda, who meditated here before beginning his spiritual journey. The boat ride to the rock is a unique experience, offering stunning views of the ocean on all sides.

A lovely quick boat ride to get there. We arrived on a marvellous sunny day. Although breezy was welcome. You do need to be aware you need to remove your shoes. Stay on light colours when walking.
Well worth the visit.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Thiruvalluvar Statue is a monumental 40-meter-high statue and pedestal located on a small island near the Vivekananda Rock Memorial in Kanyakumari. It is dedicated to the eminent Tamil poet and philosopher, Saint Thiruvalluvar, who composed 1330 profound seven-worded couplets known as Thirukkural. This work emphasizes virtues such as duty, kindness, wealth, charity, gratitude, and love for all classes of people in society.
placeMetadata.address: Kanniyakumari, Tamil Nadu, India

reviews.reviewText:
I recently visited the Thiruvalluvar Statue in Kanyakumari, and it was an unforgettable experience. The statue is located on a small island surrounded by the sea, and now there’s a newly built glass sea bridge that connects the Vivekananda Rock Memorial and the Thiruvalluvar Statue. Walking on this bridge was one of the highlights of my trip. You can see the ocean below your feet, and it gives you a thrilling and beautiful view of the surroundings.

The whole area is very clean and well-maintained. The strong sea breeze made the environment feel fresh and relaxing. It was really peaceful to stand near the statue with the wind blowing and enjoy the sound of the waves all around. The scenery is stunning, especially the view of the three oceans — the Bay of Bengal, Arabian Sea, and Indian Ocean — meeting at this point.

The Thiruvalluvar Statue itself is grand and inspiring, honoring one of Tamil Nadu’s greatest poets and philosophers. The peaceful surroundings, combined with the majestic statue and the exciting walk on the sea bridge, created a perfect mix of nature, culture, and adventure.

If you're planning a visit to Kanyakumari, I highly recommend coming early in the morning or near sunset to fully enjoy the view, wind, and light. The sea bridge adds a new dimension to the experience — it's safe, exciting, and offers fantastic photo opportunities.

Great place, need to take government operated boats for the to and fro journey from kanykumari to the statue. It's around 80 Rs to take the boat ride. By giving 300Rs fast moving line can be utilised. Nice scenic place. Try avoiding peak noon time. There is glass bridge connecting between the statue and the meditation centre which is also an attraction.

Kanyakumari is a truly mesmerizing place where nature, history, and spirituality blend beautifully. Watching the sunrise and sunset over the ocean from the same spot is a unique and unforgettable experience. The Vivekananda Rock Memorial and Thiruvalluvar Statue are both iconic landmarks worth visiting — peaceful, inspiring, and scenic.

The confluence of the Arabian Sea, Bay of Bengal, and Indian Ocean is stunning to witness. The town is clean, the locals are warm and welcoming, and there's a calm spiritual vibe everywhere. Street food is great too, especially the fresh coconut water and local snacks.

Highly recommended for anyone looking to unwind, explore Indian culture, or just enjoy coastal beauty. I'd definitely love to return!

Visited the iconic Thiruvalluvar Statue today on 15th July 25 and it was an inspiring experience! Standing tall at 133 feet, this majestic statue honors the legendary Tamil poet and philosopher Thiruvalluvar, who gifted us the timeless Thirukkural.
The view of the endless ocean all around adds to the peaceful yet powerful atmosphere. It's not just a monument—it's a symbol of ancient wisdom, Tamil pride, and universal values.

Visiting the Thiruvalluvar statue was a really memorable experience. Standing tall against the backdrop of the ocean, the statue looks so majestic and inspiring—it almost feels like it’s watching over the waves with wisdom. The boat ride to reach the statue added to the excitement, and once there, I was amazed by the sheer size and detailed craftsmanship. Being up close made me appreciate not just the beauty but also the cultural importance behind it. The only small drawback was the crowd and a bit of waiting time, but once you’re there, it’s worth it. It’s a place that makes you pause, reflect, and feel proud of such heritage. 🌊🙏

Winds are nice. But overall it's a scam place. There is too much crowd. The queue to go back to ferry ride is too big. It's better to not go there. There is nothing tonsee there. Only the glass bridge can be a okok thing to see. But the glass is tinted and u can't see much.

I have visited Kanyakumari on 7th July for the first time. It is a mesmerising destination of Tamil Nadu.  A 133 foot tall Thiruvalluvar statue worth to watch. Separate building for Vivekanandha rock memorial Hall. Here you can sit and do meditation. Glass bridge is to reach Thiruvalluvar statue is the one of the amazing experience  we can ever had. Very thrilling experience. You can take videos when you are walking on the glass bridge. It’s looks like we are walking on the water. If you reach close to Thiruvalluvar statue it’s difficult to take photo near the statue because of the height of the statue photo won’t cover the full statue. But entrance itself you can see the front view of the Thiruvalllivar statue.

Eknath Ranadeji who founded the  Vivekananda Memorial Hall, Kanyakumari,  suggested that a statue of Thiruvalluvar be erected on a nearby rock and gave the full plan, map and estimate to the then Chief Minister M. Karunanidhi .
A boat called a 'Pantoon' was purchased from Kochi to transport the stones for the construction of the statue .
On January 1, 2000, the then Chief Minister M. Karunanidhi inaugurated the statue.

One can reach here from the Vivekananda Rock through a glass bridge.

Thiruvalluvar is a Tamil poet who composed the Tamil literature called Thirukural.
His statue has been erected on a rock 30 feet above the water level where the three seas meet.

The Swami Vivekananda Memorial Hall has been erected on a rock in the middle of the Kanyakumari sea and the 133-foot-tall Thiruvalluvar statue on another rock nearby.
The Silver Jubilee is being celebrated to mark the completion of 25 years since the installation of the Thiruvalluvar statue.

A glass fibre bridge has been built to connect these two at a cost of Rs. 37 crores.
This was opened to the public on 30 th December 2024.
Thousands of people walk on this glass bridge and enjoy the beauty of the sea before reaching the Thiruvalluvar Statue area.
Tourists  went from the boat house to Vivekananda Rock walked through the glass fiber bridge and visited the Thiruvalluvar statue.

The temple is famous for the dazzling diamond nose ring adorning the deity, which has been said to lead sailors astray due to its brightness.

reviews.reviewText: Amazing temple!! You need to pay anyone anything. Just walk in to have a blessed darshan!!. Men will have to open their shirts. The temple is old, and the idol is amazing. The nose ring, which is the highlight, shines in all glory!! History has it that ships used to steer to coast seeing the shine of the nose ring!! It's really worth visiting. Views from behind temples are also good!

The temple is about 1 to 2 km from the railway station—easy to reach by walk or auto. Don’t miss the beautiful sunrise at Kanyakumari—it’s a must-see!

The deity here is very powerful and divine. For male devotees, shirts or T-shirts are not allowed inside the temple. Only dhoti or pants are allowed, and the upper body must be uncovered.

There are both free and paid darshan options available. For fresh-up, there are many clock rooms and fresh-up rooms nearby. No need to spend much on rooms—basic fresh-up facilities are available for just ₹30.

A peaceful and powerful place to visit with spiritual energy all around.

Kanyakumari, the southernmost tip of India, is a place where land, sea, and sky converge in breathtaking harmony. Renowned for its stunning sunrise views over the Bay of Bengal, it offers a serene spectacle that draws travelers from around the world. The Vivekananda Rock Memorial stands as a tribute to spiritual reflection and national pride, while the ancient Bhagavathi Amman Temple, dedicated to the goddess Kanyakumari, adds a layer of historical and cultural depth to this coastal gem.

Amman Temple is a must-visit for anyone in Kanyakumari. The temple is beautifully maintained and has a serene, spiritual atmosphere. The early morning visit is highly recommended to avoid crowds and to experience the tranquility of the place.
I visited during the early hours, just in time for the Arti   and it was incredibly peaceful. The divine energy of the temple combined with the soft chants and cool morning breeze made for a truly spiritual experience. The temple is dedicated to Goddess Kanyakumari, and the structure is magnificent, reflecting both historical significance and spiritual beauty. The temple complex is clean, and the surroundings are calming.

Good experience in the temple. Visited on a weekday evening at 6 pm (27th June)

reviews.reviewText: A fine memorial museum decicated to The Father of Our Nation , located on a beautiful seashore which he had visited and written about . After his cremation, a part of his  ashes too were consigned  to the ocean at this place . The huge hall is a very peaceful place to sit in silence and think about the life and teachings of this great man . Many rare photos from his life are exhibited as also  his sayings . Outside , we find an installation with statues of Gandhi and Kamaraja against a backdrop of gushing waves .  A must visit for all . Children, especially, need to be taken here and told about Gandhiji’s greatness.

During our visit to the Mahatma Gandhi Mandapam in Kanyakumari, we were struck by its architectural beauty and historical significance. The mandapam, built to honor Mahatma Gandhi, is situated near the confluence of the Arabian Sea, the Bay of Bengal, and the Indian Ocean, offering breathtaking views of the surrounding waters.

The structure is designed to allow sunlight to fall on the exact spot where Gandhi's ashes were kept, symbolizing his enlightenment and teachings. Inside, the serene atmosphere provides a space for reflection on Gandhi's life and principles.

Visitors have noted the cleanliness and maintenance of the site, as well as the informative displays that offer insights into Gandhi's journey and philosophy. The mandapam serves as both a tourist attraction and a place of homage, drawing individuals interested in India's history and the legacy of the Mahatma.

Overall, the Mahatma Gandhi Mandapam is a must-visit landmark in Kanyakumari, offering a blend of architectural elegance, historical depth, and scenic beauty.

A picturesque mausoleum of sorts right by the shore. It's a monument dedicated to the life and ethos of MK Gandhi. There's no entry fee, but you will have to pay a small fee at the footwear stand.

Inside, you'll witness an array of memorabilia from his early days as a barrister in South Africa all the way to his pivotal role in India's Independence. At the Memorial's center, you can see the spot where his ashes were kept before immersion.

Worth the visit if you're touring the town. You also have great views of the shoreline outside.

reviews.reviewText:
The Gandhi Memorial near Triveni is a significant tourist attraction, holding historical importance as the site where Mahatma Gandhi's ashes were kept before his final rites. The memorial beautifully chronicles Gandhi's journey from Porbandir to his final days, highlighting his pivotal role in India's freedom movement.

This iconic structure proudly showcases India's rich cultural heritage, offering insights into Gandhi's teachings, philosophy, and service to the nation. The 79-foot-high central building symbolizes Gandhi's age at the time of his passing.

A striking feature of the memorial is its architectural design, where the ceiling's opening allows sunlight to illuminate the spot where Gandhi's ashes were kept on his birth anniversary, October 2nd. The rooftop offers breathtaking panoramic views of the surrounding ocean.

Best of all, entry to the memorial is free, making it accessible to all who wish to pay their respects and learn about India's history.

Proudly upholding the rich cultural heritage of India, the Gandhi Memorial offers a clear picture of the teachings, philosophy, ideal and services rendered by Mahatma Gandhi for the country.

The central area of the building has been built in a way that stands 79 feet high, symbolizing the age of Mahatma Gandhi at the time of his demise.

The most striking feature here is the ceiling of the building. It has an opening that has been built in such a way that on every 2nd October, (birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi) rays of Sun falls exactly on the spot where his ashes were kept.

The roof of the memorial gives a beautiful panoramic view of the ocean around.

Entry to the memorial is free..

So, I heard about the amazing Kamaraja, and I really wanted to know more about him, you know?
The Kamarajar Mandapam was built to remember Mr. Kamaraj, who was the chief minister of Tamil Nadu for 13 years. He was famous for being simple and honest.
It's a great place to go, it's kept up really well, and it's super peaceful. It's a good spot for meditating, too. Plus, it's the best place to see where the rivers meet the sea and the beach. They have photos that show his life story, which is really cool. It's all organized nicely, and the surroundings are nice. It's a good place to bring the kids so they can learn about awesome people.
You don't have to pay to get in but the uncle who tells the stories about this will ask some money.

Another monument Kamarajar Manimandapam was raised and dedicated to Late. Sri. Kamarajar, The freedom fighter, Former Chief minister of Tamil Nadu, President of Indian National Congress. He was popularly known as Black Gandhi among the masses and king maker during congress regime.  He is still called by all as “Perunthalaivar”. He played vital roles in the administration of TamilNadu, by introducing education for down trodden and also started the Noon Meal scheme for the students to encourage education. Development activities like Dams and Industries in Tamilnadu took place during his rule. This monument was constructed where his ashes were kept here for public to pay homage before immersion into the sea.

Visting Hours -7 AM To 7 PM .

Kamarajar actively participated in the Indian independence movement, working alongside other prominent leaders to fight for India's freedom from British rule.

Like many other freedom fighters, Kamarajar faced imprisonment for his political activities against the British.

After India gained independence, Kamarajar continued to serve the nation as a politician. He became the Chief Minister of Madras State (now Tamil Nadu) and later served as the President of the Indian National Congress.

He is also known for his influence in Indian politics, particularly his role in elevating Lal Bahadur Shastri and Indira Gandhi to the position of Prime Minister, earning him the title "Kingmaker".

Visited on today morning it is situated near Gandhi Mandapam, offering visitors a chance to explore multiple historical sites in close proximity.  Inside, the photographic exhibits provide a comprehensive overview of Kamaraj's life, his contributions to India's political landscape, and his dedication to public service.

Kanniyakumari, the country's southernmost tip offers a diverse array of attractions, such as beaches, temples, museums, and more. One must-see attraction is the Kamarajar Manimandapam in Kanyakumari, a significant historical site dedicated to Kamarajar, a freedom fighter and former Chief Minister of Tamil Nadu.

The picturesque town of Kanyakumari was chosen by the government as the final resting place for Kamaraj's ashes, allowing people to pay their respects before the ashes are submerged in the sea, in consideration of Kingmaker Kamaraj's popularity.

Visiting Time 7Am To 7Pm

We felt a wave of disappointment wash over us. As we approached the mandapam, we became increasingly cautious, especially when we noticed a man lurking nearby, persistently asking for money. This unexpected encounter was frustrating, as we were unaware of his intentions before stepping inside. It felt as though we had been caught in a trap, and ultimately, he managed to take 200 rupees from us. It left us with a bitter experience, wishing we had been informed beforehand about this practice.

During our visit to the Kamarajar Mani Mandapam in Kanyakumari, we were deeply moved by the tribute to Shri K. Kamaraj, a revered freedom fighter and former Chief Minister of Tamil Nadu. Known as the "Black Gandhi" and "Perunthalaivar," Kamaraj was instrumental in introducing the free midday meal scheme in schools in 1962, encouraging education among the underprivileged.

The memorial is situated near the Triveni Sangam, adjacent to the Gandhi Mandapam, offering visitors a chance to explore multiple historical sites in close proximity.  Inside, the photographic exhibits provide a comprehensive overview of Kamaraj's life, his contributions to India's political landscape, and his dedication to public service.

The architecture of the mandapam is notable, blending traditional Dravidian elements with contemporary design, reminiscent of a gopuram found in South Indian temples.  The serene ambiance of the memorial offers a space for reflection on the enduring legacy of a leader who prioritized education and social welfare.

Overall, the Kamarajar Mani Mandapam stands as a significant landmark in Kanyakumari, honoring a leader whose vision and efforts have left a lasting impact on Tamil Nadu and India as a whole.

Kamarajar, as Chief Minister of Madras State (now Tamil Nadu), oversaw the construction of numerous dams during his tenure. While the exact number is not specified, several significant dams were built during his period, including the Parambikulam Dam, Lower Bhavani, Krishnagiri, Mani Muthuar, Cauvery delta, Aarani River, Vaigai Dam, Amravathi, Sathanur, Pullambadi, and Neyaru Dams.

Triveni Sangam in Kanyakumari is the point where the Arabian Sea, Bay of Bengal, and Indian Ocean meet. It is a popular pilgrimage site, with a belief that bathing in the confluence washes away sins. The meeting of these three bodies of water is considered sacred and is a major attraction in Kanyakumari.

Despite its unassuming size, the park holds great emotional weight as it commemorates the lives lost during this tragic event.

placeMetadata.name: The Hidden Twin beach

sources.snippet: This is one of the most hidden and secluded beaches in Kanyakumari, located about 12 km away from Kanyakumari Beach. The beach is known for its two adjacent beaches, which are separated by a small hill, and its rock formations, which create natural arches and bridges. The beach is also a popular spot for trekking, camping, and star gazing.
